Tolerances were chosen to prevent errors in labels, intersections, tics, overshoots, and undershoots. Tests were performed to detect these types of errors and necessary corrections were made.</logic>       <complete> Data completeness reflects the content of the source file. </complete>       <posacc>          <horizpa>             <horizpar>The root-mean square error is generally .003 map units or less.</horizpar>          </horizpa>       </posacc>       <lineage>          <srcinfo>             <srccite>                <citeinfo>                   <origin>United States Reclamation Service</origin>                   <pubdate>1914</pubdate>                   <title>United States Reclamation Service Rio Grande Project, New Mexico-Texas, Map of Mesilla Valley Showing Various Known River Channels.</title>                   <geoform>map</geoform>                   <pubinfo>                      <pubplace>United States</pubplace>                      <publish>United States Reclamation Service</publish>                   </pubinfo>                </citeinfo>             </srccite>             <srcscale>63360</srcscale>             <typesrc>paper</typesrc>             <srctime>                <timeinfo>                   <sngdate>                      <caldate>1914</caldate>                   </sngdate>                </timeinfo>                <srccurr>publication date</srccurr>             </srctime>             <srccitea>none</srccitea>             <srccontr>Linework digitized from xerox copy of original map.</srccontr>          </srcinfo>          <procstep>             <procdesc>Line work digitized from xerox copy. Tics were Township and Range section corners taken from the original map.The digitized cover was then transformed in ARC/Info using section corners derived from the Public Land Survey Section coverage from RGIS. Polygons were created from the linework and the coverage was projected into UTM coordinates.</procdesc>             <procdate>2000</procdate>             <proccont>                <cntinfo>
